The '''112th Cavalry Regiment''' was a [[Texas National Guard]] regiment that served in several Pacific campaigns during [[World War II]].
==Early history== The 112th Cavalry was first organised in 1918 as the 5th Texas Cavalry Regiment in 1918 before being disbanded in 1920.<ref>{{cite web|title=112th Cavalry Regiment 1940 <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE --> |url=http://www.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org/1940/112.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5aeHdV?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org%2F1940%2F112.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref> In December 1920 the Texas National Guard was reorganized as the [[36th Infantry Division (United States)|36th Infantry Division]] and the 1st Texas Cavalry Brigade less one regiment. On 20 July 1921 the 1st Texas Cavalry Regiment became the 112th Cavalry.<ref>{{cite web|title=124th Cavalry Regiment [Archive] – Armchair General and HistoryNet >> The Best Forums in History <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE --> |url=http://www.armchairgeneral.com/forums/archive/index.php/t-22620.html |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5YrD75?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.armchairgeneral.com%2Fforums%2Farchive%2Findex.php%2Ft-22620.html |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref> In March 1929 the 2nd Squadron and the Machine Gun Squadron of the 112th were reorganized into the 124th Cavalry Regiment. The 112th and 124th Cavalry were brigaded into the [[56th Cavalry Brigade]] in 1940.
==World War II== On 10 November 1940 President Roosevelt federalized the National Guard, and on 18 November 1940 the 112th was posted to [[Fort Bliss]].<ref name="texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org">{{cite web|title=WWII Summary History: 112th Cavalry Regiment <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE --> |url=http://www.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org/112th.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5ZEbDi?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org%2F112th.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |accessdate=2009-03-28 |deadurl=no |df=dmy }}</ref> The 112th's sister regiment in the brigade, the [[124th Cavalry Regiment (United States)|124th Cavalry]] was the last of the cavalry regiments to give up their horses and was later sent to Burma.
The regiment patrolled the Mexican border until being shipped to [[New Caledonia]] on 8 July 1942 arriving on 11 August 1942. They were assigned to the [[Americal Division]] under General [[Alexander Patch]].<ref name="texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org"/> The 112th Cavalry were assigned Australian [[Waler horse]]s, and ordered to New Caledonia to serve as a horse mounted security force. General Patch initially thought horse mounted cavalry could be used in jungle warfare, but the torrential Pacific rains and the mud that followed damaged the horses' hooves, changing the general's mind.<ref>{{cite web|title=The Motley Crew <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE --> |url=http://www.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org/112/112d.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5ZXqvm?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org%2F112%2F112d.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref> The Australian horses were shipped to [[Burma]] and assigned to Chinese forces who mistreated them. In 1944 the [[Waler horse|Waler]]s rejoined the American Army being assigned to [[Merrill's Marauders]].<ref>p.78 Ogburn Jr, Charlton ''The Marauders'' 1959 Harper</ref>
During the heavy fighting on [[Battle of Guadalcanal|Guadalcanal]], General [[Alexander Vandegrift]] of the [[1st Marine Division (United States)|1st Marine Division]] sent an urgent request for [[machete]]s for his Marines. General Patch took the sabers of the regiment, cut them down and sent them to the Marines for [[jungle warfare]] use.<ref>{{cite web|title=World War II Plus 55 – August 20th–22nd, 1942 <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE --> |url=http://www.bb56.com/worldwar2plus55/dl20au42.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5Zvbd1?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.bb56.com%2Fworldwar2plus55%2Fdl20au42.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref>
After extensive training the 112th made its first [[Amphibious warfare|amphibious landing]] at [[Woodlark Island]] as part of ''[[Operation Chronicle]]'' on 30 June 1943. The landing was unopposed, and the cavalrymen established a defensible perimeter to protect [[Seabee (US Navy)|Seabee]]s building an airstrip on the island.
The regiment was sent to [[Goodenough Island]] for training and became part of Task Force Director in preparation for its first action, [[Operation Director]] the [[Battle of Arawe]]. The 112th set sail on the USS ''[[USS Carter Hall (LSD-3)|Carter Hall]]'', HMAS ''[[HMAS Westralia (1939)|Westralia]]'' and the [[high speed transport]]s USS ''[[USS Sands (DD-243)|Sands]]'' and USS ''[[USS Humphreys|Humphreys]]''.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.ibiblio.org/hyperwar/USA/USA-P-Rabaul/USA-P-Rabaul-14.html|title=HyperWar: US Army in WWII: CARTWHEEL--The Reduction of Rabaul|work=ibiblio.org|accessdate=30 July 2016}}</ref> On 15 December 1943 the regiment landed in three separate amphibious operations on [[New Britain]]. [[File:112 RCT Arawe.jpg|thumb|left|112th RCT soldiers move through a coconut plantation at Arawe]]
One of these landings involved Troop A of the 2nd Squadron landing in rubber boats off the USS Sands against fierce defense that sank all but three of the boats. The destroyer USS ''[[USS Shaw (DD-373)|Shaw]]'' sailed close as possible to the enemy defenders to shell them and rescue the survivors of A Troop.<ref>Drea, E.J. ''Defending the Driniumor: Covering Operations in New Guinea 1944 '' 1984 Diane Publishing, p.48</ref>
Troop B landed at [[Pilelo]] Island from the USS ''Humphreys'' in 15 rubber boats on the same day. When meeting resistance from Japanese troops in caves, Troop B destroyed one with a [[bazooka]] and one with a [[flamethrower]] the first use of the weapon in the [[Southwest Pacific]] area.<ref>{{cite web|title=Chapter 14: The Flame Thrower in the Pacific: Guadalcanal to the Marshall Islands <!-- BOT GENERATED TITLE --> |url=http://www.history.army.mil/books/wwii/chemsincmbt/ch14.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5cFYhK?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.history.army.mil%2Fbooks%2Fwwii%2Fchemsincmbt%2Fch14.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref>
The main landings were from [[Landing Vehicle Tracked|amphibious tractors]] launched from the USS ''Carter Hall'' and landing craft from HMAS ''[[HMAS Westralia (1939)|Westralia]]''. In this landing the 112th Cavalry were the first to use the 4.5 inch rocket firing [[DUKW]]s.<ref>{{cite web|title=Trucking With The Duck |author=Charles H. Bogart |url=http://sill-www.army.mil/FAMAG/1983/SEP_OCT_1983/SEP_OCT_1983_PAGES_25_28.pdf |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP7NiSfp?url=http%3A%2F%2Fsill-www.army.mil%2FFAMAG%2F1983%2FSEP_OCT_1983%2FSEP_OCT_1983_PAGES_25_28.pdf |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref>
After linking up with the 1st Marine Division, the 112th was assigned to the [[32nd Infantry Division (United States)|32nd Infantry Division]] in [[Aitape]] [[Papua New Guinea]]. The regiment fought in the [[Battle of Driniumor River]] for 51 days taking 62% casualties.<ref>{{cite web|title=The World War II Lecture Institute |author=Brandon Traister <!-- BOT GENERATED AUTHOR --> |url=http://www.wwiilectureinstitute.com/stories/spurr.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5aIWlh?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.wwiilectureinstitute.com%2Fstories%2Fspurr.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref> Two of the regiment's [[second lieutenant]]s, [[Dale Eldon Christensen]] and [[George W. G. Boyce, Jr.]] were awarded the [[Medal of Honor]] for their actions during this period.
On 1 October 1944 the 112th Cavalry was combined with the 114th Field Artillery Battalion became the 112th Regimental Combat Team (RCT) and departed Aitape for [[Leyte]] in the [[Philippines]] on 31 October 1944. The 112th RCT was attached to the [[1st Cavalry Division (United States)|1st Cavalry Division]] for the [[Battle of Leyte]] and [[Battle of Luzon]].
Following the Japanese surrender, the 112th landed in Japan for Occupation Duties on 3 September 1945.
During World War II the 112th Cavalry served 434 days in combat. They were the first U.S. Army unit in the Southwest Pacific to use bazookas and flame throwers against enemy defenses and first used rocket firing DUKWs in amphibious assaults. The 112th were the first unit in the Philippines to use [[helicopter]]s to evacuate their wounded.<ref>{{cite web|title=Title Unknown |url=http://texinfo.library.unt.edu/sessionlaws/79thsession/bills/hcr/HCR6.pdf |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5bvRjx?url=http%3A%2F%2Ftexinfo.library.unt.edu%2Fsessionlaws%2F79thsession%2Fbills%2Fhcr%2FHCR6.pdf |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }} and {{cite web|title=Treasurer |url=http://www.dustoff.org/newsletter/Spring-Summer02/article-three.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5ceF8B?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.dustoff.org%2Fnewsletter%2FSpring-Summer02%2Farticle-three.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref>
Two of the regiment's late replacements authored books after the war ended. [[Norman Mailer]] wrote ''[[The Naked and the Dead]],'' and [[Francis Gwaltney]] authored ''The Day the Century Ended'', later filmed as ''[[Between Heaven and Hell (film)|Between Heaven and Hell]]''.
==Postwar== The regiment was inactivated in Japan in 1946 but was re-organized on 13 November 1947 as the 112th Mechanized Cavalry Reconnaissance Squadron, then reorganized on 12 September 1949 as the 112th Armored Cavalry Regiment.<ref>pp 28–29 Pope, Jeffrey Lynn & Kondratiuk, Leonid ''Armor-Cavalry Regiments: Army National Guard Lineage'' 1995 Diane Publishing</ref> On 16 March 1957 the regiment became the 112th Armor and was transferred to active service. In 1961 it was transferred back to the National Guard as part of the [[49th Armored Division (United States)|49th Armored Division]]. Following the disbandment of the 49th Armored Division, the 112th Armor became part of the [[56th Infantry Brigade Combat Team|56th Brigade]] of the [[36th Infantry Division (United States)|36th Infantry Division]].<ref>Globalsecurity.org, [http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/agency/army/2-112ar.htm 2nd Battalion, 112th Armor]</ref>
From 1973 all of the Texas Army National Guard armor units were renumbered as battalions of the 112th Armor. From 1988–93 eight battalions were assigned to the 112th making it then the largest armored regiment in the U.S. Army.<ref>{{cite web|title=Post World War II Texas National Guard |url=http://www.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org/articles/postwarii.htm |work= |archiveurl=http://www.webcitation.org/5gP5bYwrg?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.texasmilitaryforcesmuseum.org%2Farticles%2Fpostwarii.htm |archivedate=29 April 2009 |deadurl=no |accessdate=2009-03-28 |df=dmy }}</ref>
On 17 October 2008, the 4th Battalion, 112th Armor was renamed 1st Squadron, 112th Cavalry. The unit carries the colors and lineage of the original 112th Cavalry Regiment. The squadron Headquarters and Headquarters Troop are based in Bryan, Texas, with A Troop, B Troop and C Troop based in Taylor, Rosenberg and Ellington Field respectively. A and B Troops are equipped as cavalry units with HMMWVs, and C Troop is a dismounted infantry unit. The current commander is Lieutenant Colonel Gabe Simonds and the Command Sergeant Major is Command Sgt. Maj. Carl "Tom" Davis.
The 1st Squadron, 112th Cavalry, is part of the [[72nd Infantry Brigade Combat Team (United States)|72nd Infantry Brigade Combat Team]] of the 36th Infantry Division.
